Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation2: The nun has been chosen to represent the convent and lead a prayer vigil at a major public religious event.
Story: My phone buzzes in my pocket as I stand in the quiet chapel, the scent of incense lingering in the air. I know it’s my mother—her weekend text, a simple “How are you, dear?” She worries if I don’t reply quickly, and I can almost hear her voice, gentle but anxious, wanting to know I’m safe and well. But today, I’ve been chosen to lead the prayer vigil at the city cathedral, a rare honor for someone so new to the convent. The sisters expect me to be fully present, to guide them in devotion, to set aside all distractions. My heart aches as I glance at my phone, torn between the duty to my family and the sacred responsibility before me. I want to reassure my mother, to be the attentive daughter she raised, but the weight of my vows presses on me. The organ begins to play, signaling it’s time to take my place. My hands tremble as I tuck my phone away, caught between two worlds, each demanding a part of me I cannot give fully to both.
